resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
pitrou opened a new pull request #2308: ARROW-2514: [Python] Speed up inferring nested Numpy array
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2308
 
 
   Before:
   ```
   $ python -m timeit -s "import numpy as np, pyarrow as pa; data = [np.arange(10000)]" "pa.array(data)"
   100 loops, best of 3: 2.68 msec per loop
   ```
   
   After:
   ```
   $ python -m timeit -s "import numpy as np, pyarrow as pa; data = [np.arange(10000)]" "pa.array(data)"
   1000 loops, best of 3: 1.21 msec per loop
   ```
   
   Conversion itself is still slow, though.

wesm commented on a change in pull request #2308: ARROW-2514: [Python] Speed up inferring nested Numpy array
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2308#discussion_r204484875
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/python/builtin_convert.cc
 ##########
 @@ -204,6 +180,37 @@ class TypeInferrer {
   int64_t total_count() const { return total_count_; }
 
  protected:
+  Status VisitDType(PyArray_Descr* dtype) {
+    // This is a bit silly.  NumPyDtypeToArrow() infers a Arrow datatype
+    // for us, but we go back to counting abstract type kinds.
 
 Review comment:
   I think it's because there could be a mix of NumPy and non-NumPy things? Is there potentially a better way?

----------------------------------------------------------------

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #2308: ARROW-2514: [Python] Speed up inferring nested Numpy array
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2308#discussion_r204519816
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/python/builtin_convert.cc
 ##########
 @@ -204,6 +180,37 @@ class TypeInferrer {
   int64_t total_count() const { return total_count_; }
 
  protected:
+  Status VisitDType(PyArray_Descr* dtype) {
+    // This is a bit silly.  NumPyDtypeToArrow() infers a Arrow datatype
+    // for us, but we go back to counting abstract type kinds.
 
 Review comment:
   I don't know. In Numba we had something called type unification where, for example, `unify(int32, int64) == int64`. It may be costlier than simply incrementing counters, though.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2308#discussion_r204520425
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/python/builtin_convert.cc
 ##########
 @@ -204,6 +180,37 @@ class TypeInferrer {
   int64_t total_count() const { return total_count_; }
 
  protected:
+  Status VisitDType(PyArray_Descr* dtype) {
+    // This is a bit silly.  NumPyDtypeToArrow() infers a Arrow datatype
+    // for us, but we go back to counting abstract type kinds.
 
 Review comment:
   Makes sense. We'll need to implement a similar kind of thing here eventually to be able to create unions and so forth. 
   
   I created ARROW-2899 to track

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
Converting a nested Numpy array nested walks over the Numpy data as Python objects, even if the dtype is not "object". This makes it pointlessly slow compared to the non-nested case, and even the nested Python list case:

{code:python}
>>> %%timeit data = list(range(10000))
...:pa.array(data)
...:
746 µs ± 8.36 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000 loops each)
>>> %%timeit data = np.arange(10000)
...:pa.array(data)
...:
81.1 µs ± 57.7 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each)
>>> %%timeit data = [np.arange(10000)]
...:pa.array(data)
...:
3.39 ms ± 6.27 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100 loops each)
{code}
fields.summary: [Python] Inferring / converting nested Numpy array is very slow
